column1: Interaction between Indigenous and Official Norms:
Examples of Norm Generation in the Consumer Field in Denmark*
Britt-Mari Blegvad
Zusammenfassung: Anhand von Beispielen aus verschiedenen Poiitikbereichen diskutiert der Arti­
kel die Entstehung von verschiedenen Typen von Regeln, die Teil einer speziellen norm-orientierten
Beziehung von Käufern und Verkäufern sind. Normentstehung wird erörtert als Teil der direkten
Sozialbeziehung der Parteien und als Teil des Konfliktbehandlungsprozesses, in dem ein Dritter den
Prozeß beeinflussen kann. Die diskutierten Politikbereiche betreffen Parteien, Bürgerinitiativen,
Rechtsanwälte, Gerichte, verschiedene Beschwerdestellen, den Ombudsmann für Verbraucher und
den dänischen Rat für Verbraucherprobleme.
Recht wird als ein Normentyp unter anderen angesehen. Der Artikel handelt speziell von der Inter­
aktion von offiziellen Regelungen und indigenen Regeln, die sich in der Alltagspraxis gebildet ha­
ben. Der Artikel versucht zu zeigen, daß die Verbraucher Schwierigkeiten haben, ihren Problemen
Gehör zu verschaffen. Diese Tatsache hat die Arten der Verbraucher-Normen beeinflußt, die sich
gebildet haben.
Summary: Using examples from different fields I discuss in this paper the generation of different
types of rules as part of a special norm-oriented relation between seller and consumer Norm gener­
ation is discussed both as part of a direct social relation of the parties and as part of a dispute
treatment process whereby a third person is introduced. The arenas discussed are the parties,
grassroots groups, lawyers and courts, different types of grievance boards, the Consumer Ombuds­
man and the Danish Consumer Council.
Law is regarded as one type of norm The paper deals in particular with the interaction between
official regulations and indigenous norms. The analysis shows that consumers as a group have great
difficulties making their weight feit in the legal System. This fact has influenced the kinds of con­
sumer norms which have been developed.

II. Point of discussion
My object is to consider the generation of official and “indigenous“ norms that
aim at promoting consumer protection in Denmark.

Interaction between indigenous and official normt
In the legal community, it is a familiär perspective to regard law as the primary norm
in relation to other types of norms. This perspective has been challenged by the legal
anthropologists, which through their work have given a broader perspective to the
somewhat arbitrary character of labelling different types of rules. Sally Falk Moore
underscores that
“the law of the central state is but one kind of reglementation emanating from one kind of Organi­
zation. .
This approach takes into account that there is a constant struggle between deliberate rulemaking
and planning, and other more untameable activities and processes at work in the social aggregate,
and argues that these should be inspected together “6
One aspect of these processes is the development of indigenous norms, i. e. social or-
dering which is familiär to and applied by the participants in the everyday activity being
regulated.7 Indigenous is according to Galanter a relative Order of such Systems which
incorporate cultural elements from the unofficial and official law as well as from the
sanction System. As a matter of fact it is the interaction between the different types
of Systems which is the focus of this paper
Consumption is here regarded as a “semi-autonomous social field“, i. e. a specific
field of social activity identified not by its organization but by the fact that it can
generate rules and coerce or induce compliance to them.8 It is especially important
to underline the procedural aspect, for consumers are what David Trubek has called a
“diffuse group“ in the sense that the group is comprised of a large number of indi-
viduals who share a common interest in a specific policy.9 Promoting their basic
relation with sellers of goods and Service is a norm-oriented policy connected with
the individual’s position rather than with his person as such.10
As part of the relation between consumer and seller, norms are generated. In this proc-
ess both official, semi-official and private parties interact in a complicated pattern.
Most relevant for this discussion is norm generation as a part of the ‘filling in‘ process
one finds in areas where the general rules are not detailed but provide a frame of refer­
ence or a net of general clauses which need further interpretation. But one might also
visualize settings where the norms and Controls of indigenous ordering are close to

It is here assumed that norm generation becomes visible when the parties are in con­
flict. This takes place as part of a communication process wherein the parties do not
accept each other’s interpretation of the elements of a given Situation. The interaction
becomes thematized as a conflict. Hence also a need for regulations and other norms.
The filter for both thematization of the conflict and generation of rules is to be found
in the reference-group. The choice of the relevant reference-group is not free but deter-
mined or restricted on the macro-level by the social structure of the macro-system.13
III The Danish Situation until 1975
By the end of the sixties there was a consensus in Danish society that consumers as
such needed support. One of the results was the establishment of a governmental Con­
sumer Commission.14 This commission suggested systematic changes mostly by intro-
ducing rules from which no departure at the expense of the consumer was allowed.
Previous law was based on liberal principles securing presumably equal parties a right
to solve their problems by bargaining. As a consequence commercial customs devel-
oped in certain lines of business. But the commission stated that very few customs reg­
ulating the Situation of the consumer had developed. Fürther the consumer very
rarely went to court, so the legal System lacked systematic knowledge about norms
regulating such buying and selling within the different trades and lines of business.
There were some twenty private complaint boards of differing importance. They were
economically dependent on trade organizations and to some extent endorsed by the
Consumer Council — a council of societies concerned to promote good housekeeping
that was at that time supported by the Danish Government — which also ran a com­
plaint bureau. The boards had often been established as part of a self-controlling
System of the line of business, and the rather meagre results of their activity were also
used as part of self-promotion campaigns. One did not know whether these agencies
also served the interests of the consumer.

Interaction between indigenous and official norms
Therefore the commission suggested setting up a Consumer-ombudsman-, it further
suggested that an official Consumer Tribunal should be established to control the
activity of the private boards. This Tribunal should also treat cases in some of the
fields where the private boards lacked competence. It was explicitly stated that these
two official agencies would not only deal with single cases but also contribute to
general norm generation.
IV. The development of rules after 1975
I will here deal with the activity of the parties and grassroots groups as well as with
what is going on in the existing agencies — the courts, the special boards and the
Consumer Tribunal — and the activity of the Consumer-ombudsman. Mutual contacts
will be the focus.
The most important way of developing norms in this field of social activity is probably
through direct contact between the consumer and the seller As already suggested,
their basic relation is a norm-oriented one connected with the individual's position.
Usually the parties just meet each other as consumer or seller of goods or Services.
Their contact might be frequent or a one-shot affair. The essential point, however, is
that the parties regard each other not as Joe or Mary but as seller and customer. The
essential frame of reference is a norm System.
When everything runs smoothly the parties are only vaguely aware of the content of
this reference System. In economic relations most parties know something about the
general rules governing the notion that “a deal is a deal“. But they presumably do not
know at exactly which stage a deal becomes legally binding. It is when problems occur
that the parties begin to question the binding force of the existing frame of reference.
We have a result from a Danish poll study of 1977 regardmg persons’ experiences in
consumer relations. Of those interviewed, 23 per cent had experienced problems relat-
ed to consumption. Of these, 56 per cent had discussed the problem directly with
the responsible adversary. But the distribution of those entering a bargaining Situation
differ according to age and education. The weak consumer — who in Denmark, as in
other countries, is either unskilled and young or old — rarely has the resources for a
direct challenge.15
It is difficult to find examples developed through direct contacts between sellers and
consumer. But some department Stores exchange merchandise, for example, within a
certain period after the deal is made even if the störe has no legal Obligation to do so.
Some even let the buyer cancel the deal free of Charge as part of a promotion System
based on the principle that the customer is always right — and if treated so will return.
Other shops - mostly small boutiques, aiming at young people — observe rules regard-
ing remedy which are much stricter than the ones stated by law, gambling on the fact
that young people who buy there very rarely return and do not have any knowledge
about the rules in question or complaint possibilities.16

Another possibility might be through contacts between the consumer and a consumer
grassroots group. The first group of this kind was established by 1966, inspired by the
development in England. Until 1973, the number had only grown to fourteen but by
then the number grew quickly and in four years reached about fifty. The level of
activity varies, however, considerably — two groups treat over 2.000 cases a year while
the level of others is around 30 cases. Like the official Tribunal and the semiofficial
boards, discussed below, these groups both give advice and treat special grievances. Ten
groups have special Offices manned by voluntary counsellors who sometimes act as
mediators. Only one group has a Professional paid Staff — paid through governmental
funds. Some of the groups do, however, get small local-government grants.
The mediators are lay men but use the material distributed by the offical and semi-
offical boards as background for their activity. But compared with these agencies the
grassroots groups have wider scope, for they also deal with complaints against the local
and state service in communication, health, etc.
It should also be mentioned that the local governments have statutory power to estab-
lish a special social consumer council with the aim of advising the local government in
social planning. Such councils have, so far at any rate, had a very low level of penetra­
tion. In some of the Councils the local grassroots groups are represented and this fact
seems to have had an impact on their efficiency.17189
Within this rather vague framework indigenous rules develop. From the reports of the
professionally-staffed consumer grassroots group I will mention the following exam-
ples:
“A neighbour of an old lady who was hospitalized and in intensive care tumed to the office and
asked for help as the semi-officially run telephone Company threatened to disconnect the lady’s
telephone if the fee was not payed within a very short period. The lady had no close relatives.
Thanks to the Intervention of the consumer group’s office the Company did not disconnect the
telephone and furthermore withdrew the Claim for an additional fee (case 1142).“1’
This might be regarded as an important example of an area where the official Tribunal
has only recently raised the question of its competence. The second example deals
with a problem where the official and semi-official boards, ostensibly for economic
reasons, would not interfere:
“A young lady had observed that there was a big difference between the weight of rolls.
The consumer group’s office tumed to the Registrar of Restrictive Trade Practices. There were no
special rules on this issue but one would act and a notice would be issued applicable from July 1.
One might question whether the rules here mentioned are ‘indigenous1 in the sense
used by Sally Falk Moore and Marc Galanter. As far as I can see they are, given the

type of social relation we are discussing. The norms are mostly developed on the
seller’s side, owing to the disparity in knowledge and resources between the parties.
The seilet often has easier access to expert advisors — legal commercial etc. — and to
support front his trade organization. But most essential: the seller knows the ropes,
since commerce is his job, his fare every day of the week. Being a consumer is only one
aspect of most people’s life: job, family, recreation may take more time and interest.
As already indicated, the consumer group as such is rather diffuse. This also means
that consumer organzations run on a voluntary basis like grassroots groups and can
only give the consumer limited support when developing new norms. Granted, then,
so far as we know very few general rules regarding consumer protection are self-im-
posed, we may turn to norms developed by official or semi-official organizations
which in one sence or another represent the consumer.20
The most important such organization today is the aforementioned Consumer Council,
which has developed from an organization promoting good housekeeping to a consumer
organization which has deliberately changed its policy from person Orientation to
System Orientation. The organization uses most of its resources to develop and pro­
mote consumer protection law. The council has, however, rather limited resources. It
must fight, every year, for governmental support of 700.000 U.S. dollar. On the other
hand the personel does represent Denmark in international organizations such as the
Common Market as well as in national agencies such as the Maritime and Commercial
Court, the Consumer Tribunal and eight of the twelve existing officially approved
complaint boards. It also runs a complaint agency of its own. The council further
Supports grassroots consumer groups by organizing courses in consumer problems.
But this work is not formalized. Still, through all these activities the council acquires
a broad knowledge of current consumer problems. On the other hand it is understand-
able that the council has difficulties in following up on all these diverse tasks. The
depth of its penetration into the general, economic System is therefore rather low.
While, for example, trade organizations are represented in all the committees estab-
lished by the Ministry of Commerce, the Consumer Council only had representatives
in 17 per cent of these committees.
Consumers as voters might also influence the consumer policy of the political parties
represented in the legal assembly. The political parties as such do not put a high prior-
ity on consumer policy. The most important political result was the Consumer Com­
mission. The commission was established as a result of a Propaganda drive by the Con­
sumer Counsel, which, in 1969, was threatened by a complete withdrawal of state
support. The council pointed to the Situation in the other Scandinavian countries
where consumer protection was far more highly developed and used this as a Standard
of reference.21
In the field of norm generation the work of the commission resulted in four proposals:

More important, however, are the new rules suggested by the Commission which attack
the center of the consumer’s legal Status, the private law Statutes regarding commerce,
trade and agreements. These Statutes all go back to the beginning of this Century. As a
result of the work in the Consumer Commission, a chapter concerning the special
rights of the consumer was added. The consumer was protected on certain points such
as acquiring a right of redress. Previously the parties could contract themselves out of
most regulations in the previously mentioned acts. This device was used in particular
by powerful branches such as automobile dealers, which developed for their sales units
very favourable Standard contracts. Today the consumer is at least formally protected
by the rules in the new chapter of the Sale of Goods Act.
The Consumer Commission also discussed changes in the marketing policy. As a result
of these discussions some changes in the law containing rules about ethicals Standards
for marketing and advertising were suggested. While this law previously was formulated
so as to safeguard undue competition between sellers, the rules were now changed to
facilitate the protection of both the seller and the consumer. Henceforth no form
should use incorrect, misleading or inadequate declarations which could influence de-
mand.
Finally the commission suggested a law banning different forms of door-to-door sales
and canvassing. We will return to this Statute in the following section.
It should be noted here that the legal norms guaranteeing consumer protection in Den-
mark are part of public and civil law — not penal law. The police become involved
only when fraud reaches a certain sum of money. The head of the Consumer Tribunal
after having stated the first 100 cases against an individual offering a private protection
Service which turned out to be without any value, tried to contact the prosecutor. The
latter turned down the Suggestion of prosecution, for the sum involved in each case
was only $ 25 a year. A class-action is not possible in Denmark.
Where, then, does one turn with a consumer problem? As previously mentioned, one
might seek counsel from a local consumer group which, depending on its resources,
might simply advise the party to take action himself or refer him to the existing
agencies. According to the general philosophy of the legal System, on the orther hand,
he could be assisted by a la-wyer and go to court. Has the legal profession in its general
counseling of the population contributed to the development of consumer protection
rules? We have no direct studies to refer to22. But we know that legal advice is ex-
pensive in Denmark and further that there are very few special legal aid offices which
could presumably serve as an alternative. The existing agencies deal with family and
housing problems, not with consumer problems. When lawyers enter the picture, they

do so on the seller’s side. The lawyers then represent ‘Repeat-players’23 such as a
book-selling agency which was the adversary in 130 out of 750 cases handled by the
Consumer Tribunal during the years 1975—1976.
The sellers control the norm generation in which lawyers take part. This is, as Aubert
has remarked, most clearly seen in the development of customs very close to common
law 24 The business commissions new legal “inventions“ like the above mentioned
Standard contracts; new forms of contracts such as leasing and new forms of business
associations such as Investment societies. These inventions again carry the consumer
over from the protected area into a free one.
Consumer protection may also be the result of decisions at court — a matter, here, of
case lav>. But cases regarding consumer protection are very rarely brought. Denmark
has no special System of small Claims settlement although the possibility has been dis-
cussed. Consumer cases handled according to law can be heard in court. The District
Courts, however, serve as a debt collection agency in 98 per cent of the cases presented
at the trial level, some 225,000, which concern “rights of property and taxes“ presented
by the seller Fürther the seller can use a simplified procedure — some 50,000 cases a
year — through which, based on a special purchase and instalment contract System, he
can direct the sheriff to demand the goods.
After the Consumer Tribunal was established in 1975, a very limited number of con­
sumer cases have been sent from this tribunal to court and vice versa,25 and compared
to the number of cases discussed here, they are of no importance. So case law in the
field of consumer protection is not developed in the courts. Where than?
We may ask what happens at the private complaint boards.26 Today there are twelve
approved boards, all of them connected to lines of trade. Some of them— especially
the older ones from the beginning of the sixties — are technically oriented towards
solving special problems like establishing Standards for laundry and dry cleaning or
Standards for the durability of domestic hardware. But here the problems become
more complicated because the guarantee rules collide with an assumed period of
duration.
The technical rules are, however, linked to the legal norms regarding a seller’s or Serv­
ice renderer’s duty to disclose certain material facts about his product — if, indeed,
the consumer knows what questions to put.

More essential today are the boatds dealing with hardware, which is one of the more
important areas for grievances. Here vital Cooperation between the grassroots groups
and the special boards has taken place, as a means of developing, for example, rules
regarding the formulation of guarantee clauses which previously had varied between
the different firms and types of goods.
Another example of a more legally oriented board is the one established in 1975 to
treat complaints regarding insurance contracts. This board was established partly
as an evasive means of Controlling to as great a degree as possible the treatment of con-
flicts within the business. The board has also been successful in this respect, for a
growing number of cases are being presented.
Insurance is a matter for specially trained experts and the representatives of the con­
sumer do not have the resources to hire their own. Even if the representatives of the
consumers try to question, for example, certain clauses in the insurance contracts,
they do not have the necessary resources to formulate and press their Claims for more
comprehensible formulations. A special problem has been the difference between
negligance and accidents which the insurance Companies do not cover. Only legal for­
mulations are used during the sessions and we have not found any trace of indigenous
rules.
Several important lines of business such as automobile sales and repairs, and construc-
tion, do not have any special complaint boards. These are areas where the consumers
in the aforementioned poll study especially expressed a need for easily accessible dis­
pute Settlement agencies.
The official Consumer Tribunal could be an alternative here. Although this tribunal is
explicitly supposed to treat conflicts in fields not covered by the approved boards,
the Ministry of Commerce has not yet enlarged its competence to automobiles and
constructions — partly because of the costs involved and partly because the trade
organizations are against it. The Consumer Tribunal’s role in these conflicts was al-
ready discussed by the Consumer Commission at the beginning of the seventies. These
two trades have so far succeeded in keeping the control of the dispute treatment and
of norm generation within the trade. These are examples of fields where we find
nongeneration of both indigenous and other rules. Recently, however, a complaint
board for prefabricated houses has been established. The economic depression has
probably contributed to this development.
Interaction between indigenous and official normt
The Consumer Tribunal is, furthermore, competent only in cases of a limited value —
up to $ 1,800 — and in certain enumerated fields such as sale of clothing, shoes, furni-
ture, etc. as well as sale of certain types of nonprofessional Services. Lawyers and doc-
tors are intentionally left out. These are again examples of fields where consumers in
different poll studies have expressed a need for a complaint board with equal represen­
tation of both the consumer and the renderer of the Service. So far these professions
too, have been successful in maintaining control over the way complaints against them
are handled. Norm generation in favour of the consumer has not occurred.
The Consumer Tribunal has, however, been very active in norm generation. In 1980
the agency received 12,850 inquiries, mostly over the phone. Of these 9,800 were
settled directly over the phone by subordinate personnel by either asking the consumer
to negotiate directly with the seller first or by referring him to other agencies or
to court or by telling him that he had no chance in getting any help.27 With Macaulay
one might say that the personnel here take over roles which lawyers did not wish to
play. The members act both as legal technicians, Information brokers, and gate keep-
ers.28 '
The agency then had the remaining 3,000 cases to deal with. The secretariat settled
2,200 of these by suggesting that the parties, for example, divide the costs and take
the benefits of a quick Settlement. This practice is advantageous for the board, for
it cuts the costs involved in dispute Settlement and hence conciliatory activities are
encouraged. The members of the secretariat, who are either legally trained or are
persons with experience in conflict Settlement, fall back on the sorts of arguments
used in any bargaining Situation and have thereby developed certain indigenous rules.
They use more discretion than does the tribunal in Session.
The personnel do however lean on expert opinions, which are used to a great extent,
and also on previous decisions by the Tribuanl. They tacitly assume the general policy
of the Tribunal. The staff's ambition is that a Settlement administered by them will
withstand reexamination.29 It may be noted that a consumer will not always ob-
tain, by means of this conciliatory approach, the benefits he might well obtain by
going to court.
The Tribunal has further concentrated its activity on certain areas and developed there
a kind of case law. Door-to-door sales of protection Services for elderly people is one
such area and promotion of correspondance courses for young people another. Here
the Tribunal has cooperated with the Consumer Ombudsman. He attacks the seller by
questioning the type of contract used, claiming that formulations employed are against
the general code of practice. The Ombudsman negotiates but can also bring cases to
court. This has, however, not happened. Instead, the Ombudsman has developed cer­
tain requirements that he recommends different sorts of businesses to follow.

V. A story about norm generation
Already in 1967, the question regarding legal rules prohibiting door-to-door sales was
discussed in the Nordic Council and sent to a nordic Commission for further consider-
ation. The Danish group did not, in 1970, regard enactment of such rules in Denmark
necessary.
But this question was continually taken up by consumers in the press. They wrote
about their experiences to complaint columns in newspapers. In the beginning of the
seventies two parties in particular became notorious for canvassing so-called protection
Services for elderly people. The sellers used rough methods and intimidated a number
of people into signing irrevocable contracts. The signers then had the bürden of proof.
They had to be able to show that the contract was empty. This was very difficult and
quite a number of persons over the years payed substantial sums to the so-called Serv­
ice Companies. Class action is not allowed in Denmark, and the police had no basis for
taking action since the sums involved in each case were limited. The Consumer Com­
mission however reached a different conclusion from that of the Danish group of the
Nordic commission. This was owing to the debate in which new indigenous norms
against the practice were aired by consumers. The man in the Street could not under-
stand that the law was on the side of the swindler. The indigenous rule was therefore
against the consumer‘s being bound by the deal.
Furthermore the consumers were more strongly represented in the commission than in
the group. In 1975, one reached a new consensus. Legal rules banning door-to-door
sales were suggested as part of the reform program of the Commission. These rules
should be part of the System of public legal protection for the consumer. At the same
time it was suggested that a rule in the Sale of Goods Act be introduced, making all
contracts entered in the course of door-to-door sales invalid. Here we find an attempt
to establish consumer protection through a combination of public and private law. No
special penal measures were suggested.
In 1975, both the Consumer Ombudsman and the Consumer Tribunal were established.
Very quickly both these agencies received cases regarding door-to-door sales and acted
according to their means. They furthermore supported the drafting of the law by
offering in their yearly reports substantial evidence that canvassing was a major prob­
lem for several groups in the society.
A poll from 1975 also showed that about half of the population sometimes were visited
by canvassers. Many, roughly 50 per cent, stated that they feit harassed by these
agents. As indicated earlier elderly people in particular were against these business
methods. About 58 per cent of the entire sample wanted a law as a remedy.
In 1978, a proposal following the lines suggested by the Consumer Commission was
therefore introduced into the legal assembly by the social democratic government. It
Interaction between indigenous and official normt
prompted Opposition from primarily the conservative party and was quickly passed on
to a subcommittee. Here, according to custom, different organizations presented their
views. Two lobbies are worth mentioning: The Danish publishers’ association pointed
out that about 50,000 contracts per year (Sic!) were enforced through solicitation.
This meant a sale of about $ 5 million. The association further argued that the books
sold were of a certain literary value, but did not mention that Denmark in relation to
its size has a very large number of book shops. The organization instead suggested the
introduction of a cooling-off period of one week after the reception of the goods.
The other lobby was the Association of Insurance Companies, which claimed that be-
tween 70 and 90 per cent of the Insurance deals were made through door-to-door sales.
A banning of this practice would lead to unadequate insurance coverage and great
damage to Danish society.
Both lobbies were successful. Sale of books and of insurance were made explicit excep-
tions and a cooling-off period as suggested was introduced. With these changes the law
was passed with 90 votes for and 60 against — those against still coming from the con­
servative wing. The Consumer Council tried in vane to argue for a general clause against
canvassing but lost. The two lobbies were too Strong. The result was a rule which the
people who needed protection could not handle. Inquiries made by the public to the
three agencies after the law was passed verify this Statement.30
The example given here also shows how nongeneration is brought about by strong
lobbying groups, thus hindering the transformation of indigenous rules into law. Either
they have limited resources like the Consumer Council or they lack political Support
like the Consumer Ombudsman and the Consumer Tribunal. As result of political com-
promises these organizations have no voice. They are only allowed to treat problems of
limited importance. Aubert has described a similar case of political compromise where
a labour regulation law was introduced but with the sanctions removed. Furthermore,
the rules were made so complicated that not even legal experts could handle them.31
IV. Concluding remarks
The aim of this paper is to contribute to the discussion of the generation of official
and “indigenous“ rules aimed at promoting and developing consumer protection.
Using examples from different areas I discussed the generation of different types of
rules as part of a special norm-like social interaction between seller and consumer.
With the Danish Consumer Commission I have asked how one could further the devel­
opment of consumer protection and especially customs regulating the consumer’s
Situation. The commission believed that law was the remedy. 1 have assumed that indig­
enous regulations rather than law would further the consumer’s protection in the
sense that the consumer could directly participate in and influence the development of
the rules.

I further assumed that such generation could take place in different areas in which the
consumer had problems. Therefore norm generation has been discussed both as an
aspect of the direct social relations between the parties and as an aspect of a dispute
treatment process in which a third person could influence the process.
Here 1 discussed, first, the role of the parties, with respect to which there is very little
direct Information in the available material. But since the consumers form a very dif­
fuse group, their chances of influence is rather meager. Consumers have, however, in
the seventies in growing numbers entered consumer grassroots groups which although
they only contain 5,000 members have had some inpact on the development of indig-
enous norms. We find examples of cooperation between these groups and the semi-
official and official agencies in the sense that the groups suggest Solutions which are
taken up and used by the agencies. These Solutions draw on indigenous norms such as
the one given in the example of the elderly lady (p. 11).
1 further examined the role of traditional legal agents such as lawyers and judges. Pre-
sumably they contribute only to a limited extent to the generation of rules regarding
consumer protection. This applies both to official and indigenous rules. Rather, these
agents are used to safeguard the interests of the seller.
The official Consumer Commission had established further, as part of its reform pro­
gram, two new official agencies, the Consumer Ombudsman and an official Consumer
Tribunal, with the explicit goal of developing and promoting consumer protection by
contributing to norm generation. The activities of these agencies as well as those of the
existing private boards were therefore examined from this point of view.
Some examples of indigenous rules were given and it was shown how these rules were
fitted into the official legal System. Some everyday areas of consumption like laundry
and dry cleaning were compared with sophisticated areas such as Insurance and the
use of the Professional Services of doctors and lawyers. Furthermore, one special area,
door-to-door sales, was analysed and the history of the generation of rules against can-
vassing as an aspect of the development of consumer protection rules was sketched.
Law seems very rarely be the way of establishing consumer protection, even if the
amendment of the Sale of Goods Act may be regarded as a Step forward. This law has,
however, a direct impact only within the legal System where the “Haves“ — that is, the
sellers — still dominate the picture.
Galanter has also pointed out that the messages disseminated by courts and other agen­
cies do not carry any weight or produce effects unless these are received and interpre-
ted by (potential) actors.32
Therefore, this type of dissemination is also dependent on the existing communica-
tion network. Obviously the grassroots groups and some organizations serve as such a
network. But the goal of the consumers is vague. The shared values are so general that
they do not provide any Support, as is shown in the case of the law prohibiting can-
vassing.
In Order to obtain power the different special consumer agencies have chosen to adapt
themselves to the legal System in Order to influence its development. When doing so

Interaction between indigenous and official norms
they have been forced to absorb the uncertainty of common-sence formulations which
are part of the indigenous norms and transform the language of these rules into the
technical legal language.33 All of the information given about the relations of the par­
ties has to be summed up and edited in a certain way in Order to fit it into the legal
scheme which is the general frame of reference of these agencies. The consumer, there-
fore, has obvious difficulty in using his indigenous norm System. He will soon discover
that when given a form to fill in, which is necessary in bringing a case or when the
representatives of the secretariat ask him to give the relevant information, the indige­
nous norms have no weight. The agencies decide what is relevant. Already at this stage
distance has been created.
The consumer seems to have participated most significantly in developing norms in
factual areas. There he has some force. But as soon as the legal element becomes strong
— as in consumers' relations with Professionals — the consumer has no chance. Also,
representatives of the consumers who play a role as lay judges in the agencies here
discussed have great difficulties even if they are “professional“ people who work
within the consumer of organizations. They have so few economic resources. 1t all
then boils down to a question of economic resources and power.
But in a country like Denmark, the degree of Organization also plays a role. The sellers
have their various trade organizations which are to a certain extent in economic con­
trol of the complaint boards. The consumers are not well organized — consumption
being only one aspect of most people’s life, a life in which one’s job and family recrea-
tion presumably take more time and command more interest.
I will therefore end this paper by pointing to the type of social relations of the par­
ties that are essential for the norms developed. If their relations are normative in na­
ture, as assumed here, we will find few indigenous norms but many semi-official and
official types of rule.
